column1: Published as a conference paper at ICLR 2020  SELF: LEARNING TO FILTER NOISY LABELS WITH SELF-ENSEMBLING  Duc Tam Nguyen ∗
column2: Chaithanya Kumar Mummadi ∗†
column3: Thi Phuong Nhung Ngo †
column4: Thi Hoai Phuong Nguyen ‡
column6: Thomas Brox †  ABSTRACT  Deep neural networks (DNNs) have been shown to over-fit a dataset when be- ing trained with noisy labels for a long enough time.To overcome this problem
column7: we present a simple and effective method self-ensemble label filtering (SELF) to progressively filter out the wrong labels during training.Our method improves the task performance by gradually allowing supervision only from the potentially non-noisy (clean) labels and stops learning on the filtered noisy labels.

column2: we form running averages of predictions over the entire training dataset using the network output at different training epochs.We show that these en- semble estimates yield more accurate identification of inconsistent predictions throughout training than the single estimates of the network at the most recent training epoch.While filtered samples are removed entirely from the supervised training loss
column3: we dynamically leverage them via semi-supervised learning in the unsupervised loss.

column1: We demonstrate the positive effect of such an approach on var- ious image classification tasks under both symmetric and asymmetric label noise and at different noise ratios.It substantially outperforms all previous works on noise-aware learning across different datasets and can be applied to a broad set of network architectures. 1  INTRODUCTION  The acquisition of large quantities of a high-quality human annotation is a frequent bottleneck in applying DNNs.
There are two cheap but imperfect alternatives to collect annotation at large scale: crowdsourcing from non-experts and web annotations
column2: particularly for image data where the tags and online query keywords are treated as valid labels.Both these alternatives typically introduce noisy (wrong) labels.While Rolnick et al (2017) empirically demonstrated that DNNs can be surprisingly robust to label noise under certain conditions
column3: Zhang et al (2017) has shown that DNNs have the capacity to memorize the data and will do so eventually when being confronted with too many noisy labels.

column2: training DNNs with traditional learning procedures on noisy data strongly deteriorates their ability to generalize – a severe problem.Hence
column3: limiting the inﬂuence of label noise is of great practical importance. A common approach to mitigate the negative inﬂuence of noisy labels is to eliminate them from the training data and train deep learning models just with the clean labels (Fr´enay & Verleysen

column1: Employing semi-supervised learning can even counteract the noisy labels (Laine & Aila
column2: 2016; Luo et al
column3: 2018).However
column4: the decision which labels are noisy and which are not is decisive for learning robust models.Otherwise
column5: unfiltered noisy labels still inﬂuence the (supervised) loss and affect the task performance as in these previous works.

column1: They use the entire label set to compute the loss and severely lack a mechanism to identify and filter out the erroneous labels from the labels set. In this paper
column2: we propose a self-ensemble label filtering (SELF) framework that identifies potentially noisy labels during training and keeps the network from receiving supervision from the filtered noisy labels.This allows DNNs to gradually focus on learning from undoubtedly correct samples even with an extreme level of noise in the labels (e.g.
column3: 80% noise ratio) and leads to improved performance as the supervision become less noisy.

column1: The key contribution of our work is progressive filtering
column2: i.e.

column2: the network receives noisy updates and hence ﬂuctuates strongly.Such conduct of training would impede to learn stable neural representations and further mislead the consensus of the predictions.Therefore
column3: it is essential to incorporate a model with stable training behavior to obtain better estimates from the consensus.

column4: such as proposed by Tarvainen & Valpola (2017)
column5: a.k.a. the Mean-Teacher model.This model ensemble learning provides a more stable supervisory signal than the noisy model snapshots and provides a stable ground for progressive filtering to filter out potential noisy labels.

column1: Note that this is different from just a mere combination of semi-supervised techniques with a noisy label filtering method. We call our approach self-ensemble label filtering (SELF) - that establishes model ensemble learning as a backbone to form a solid consensus of the self-ensemble predictions to filter out the noisy labels progressively.Our framework allows to compute supervised loss on cleaner subsets rather than the entire noisy labeled data as in previous works.
It further leverages the entire dataset
column2: including the filtered out erroneous samples in the unsupervised loss.To best of our knowledge
column3: we are the first to identify and propose self-ensemble as a principled technique against learning under noisy labels. Our motivation stems from the observation that DNNs start to learn from easy samples in initial phases and gradually adapt to hard ones during training.

column1: When trained on wrongly labeled data
column2: DNNs learn from clean labels at ease and receive inconsistent error signals from the noisy labels before over-fitting to the dataset.The network’s prediction is likely to be consistent on clean samples and inconsistent or oscillates strongly on wrongly labeled samples over different training iterations.Based on this observation
column3: we record the outputs of a single network made on different training epochs and treat them as an ensemble of predictions obtained from different individual networks.

column1: We call these ensembles that are evolved from a single network self-ensemble predictions.Subsequently
column2: we identify the correctly labeled samples via the agreement between the provided label set and our running average of self-ensemble predictions.The samples of ensemble predictions that agree with the provided labels are likely to be consistent and treated as clean samples.
our SELF framework stabilizes the training process and improves the generalization ability of DNNs.We evaluate the proposed technique on image classification tasks using CI- FAR10
column3: CIFAR100 & ImageNet.We demonstrate that SELF consistently outperforms the existing approaches on asymmetric and symmetric noise at all noise levels
column4: as shown in Fig 1.

column2: SELF remains robust towards the choice of the network architecture.Our work is transferable to other tasks without the need to modify the architecture or the primary learning objective. 2  Published as a conference paper at ICLR 2020  Figure 2: Overview of the self-ensemble label filtering (SELF) framework.

column1: 2 SELF-ENSEMBLE LABEL FILTERING  2.1 OVERVIEW  Fig 2 shows an overview of our proposed approach.In the beginning
column2: we assume that the labels of the training set are noisy.The model attempts to identify correct labels progressively using self- forming ensembles of models and predictions.

column1: Since wrong labels cause strong ﬂuctuations in the model’s predictions
column2: using ensembles is a natural way to counteract noisy labels. Concretely
column3: in each iteration
column4: the model learns from a detected set of potentially correct labels and maintains a running average of model snapshots (realized by the Mean Teacher model Tarvainen & Valpola (2017)).This ensemble model is evaluated on the entire dataset and provides an additional learning signal for training the single models.

column2: our framework maintains the running- average of the model’s predictions for the filtering process.The model is trained until we find the best model w.r.t. the performance on the validation set (e.g.
column3: by early-stopping).The set of correct labels is detected based on the strategy defined in Sec.

column2: we again use all data and the new filtered label set as input for the model training.The iterative training procedure stops when no better model can be found.In the following
column3: we give more details about the combination of this training and filtering procedure.

column1: 2.2 PROGRESSIVE LABEL FILTERING  Progressive detection of correctly labeled samples Our framework Self-Ensemble Label Filter- ing (Algorithm 1) focuses on the detection of certainly correct labels from the provided label set L0.In each iteration i
column2: the model is trained using the label set of potentially correct labels Li. At the end of each iteration
column3: the model determines the next correct label set Li+1 using the filtering strategy described in 2.2 The model stops learning when no improvement was achieved after training on the refined label set Li+1. In other words
column4: in each iteration
column5: the model attempts to learn from the easy

column2: learning from easy samples also affects similar but harder samples from the same classes.Therefore
column3: by learning from these easy samples

column3: take a cat wrongly labeled as a tiger.

column1: Other cat samples would encourage the model to predict the given cat image as a cat.Contrary
column2: the wrong label tiger regularly pulls the model back to predict the cat as a tiger.Hence
column3: using the model’s predictions gathered in one single training epoch for filtering is sub-optimal.

column2: in our framework SELF
column3: our model relies on ensembles of models and predictions. Model ensemble with Mean Teacher A natural way to form a model ensemble is by using an exponential running average of model snapshots (Fig.3a).

column1: This idea was proposed in Tarvainen & Valpola (2017) for semi-supervised learning and is known as the Mean Teacher model.In our framework
column2: both the mean teacher model and the normal model are evaluated on all data to preserve the consistency between both models.The consistency loss between student and teacher output distribution can be realized with Mean-Square-Error loss or Kullback-Leibler-divergence.

column4: α is a momentum

column3: a maximal number of iterations for filtering can be set to save time. 3 RELATED WORKS  Reed et al (2014); Azadi et al (2015) performed early works on learning robustly under label noise for deep neural networks.

column2: Rolnick et al (2017) have shown for classification that deep neural networks come with natural robustness to label noise following a particular random distribution.No modification of the network or the training procedure is required to achieve this robustness.Following this insight
column3: our framework SELF relies on this natural robustness to kickstart the self-ensemble filtering process to extend the robust behavior to more challenging scenarios.

column1: Laine & Aila (2016); Luo et al (2018) proposed to apply semi-supervised techniques on the data to counteract noise.These and other semi-supervised learning techniques learn from a static
column2: initial set of noisy labels and have no mechanisms to repair labels.Therefore
column3: the supervised losses in their learning objective are typically high until the model strongly overfits to the label noise.

column2: our framework performs a variant of self-supervised label corrections.The network learns from a dynamic
column3: variable set of labels
column4: which is determined by the network itself.Progressive filtering allows the network to (1) focus on a label set with a significantly lower noise ratio and (2) repair wrong decisions made by itself in an earlier iteration.

column1: Other works assign weights to potentially wrong labels to reduce the learning signal (Jiang et al
column2: 2017; Ren et al
column3: 2018; Jenni & Favaro
column4: 2018).These approaches tend to assign less extreme weights or hyperparameters that are hard to set.Since the typical classification loss is highly non-linear
column5: a lower weight might still lead to learning from wrong labels.

column2: the samples in SELF only receive extreme weights: either they are zero or one.Further
column3: SELF focuses only on self-detecting the correct samples
column4: instead of repairing the wrong labels.Typically
column5: the set of correct samples are much easier to detect and are sufficiently representative to achieve high performance.

column1: Han et al (2018b); Jiang et al (2017) employ two collaborating and simultaneously learning net- works to determine which samples to learn from and which not.However
column2: the second network is free in its predictions and hence hard to tune.Compared to these works
column3: we use ensemble learning as a principled approach to counteract model ﬂuctuations.

column2: the second network is extremely restricted and is only composed of running averages of the first network.To realize the second network
column3: we use the mean-teacher model (Tarvainen & Valpola
column4: 2017) as a backbone.Compared to their work
column5: our self-ensemble label filtering gradually detects the correct labels and learns from them
column6: so the label set is variable.

column4: Zhang & Sabuncu (2018); Thulasidasan et al (2019) propose other forms of cross-entropy losses.

column1: This result indicates that their proposed frameworks are not always compatible with semi-supervised losses. The progressive filtering technique is seamlessly compatible with different semi-supervised losses.The filtering outperforms its counterparts when combined with Entropy Learning or Mean-teacher model.

column2: SELF outperforms all considered combinations. 9  Published as a conference paper at ICLR 2020  5 CONCLUSION  We propose a simple and easy to implement a framework to train robust deep learning models under incorrect or noisy labels.We filter out the training samples that are hard to learn (possibly noisy labeled samples) by leveraging ensemble of predictions of the single network’s output over different training epochs.

we allow clean supervision from the non-hard samples and further leverage additional unsupervised loss from the entire dataset.We show that our framework results in DNN models with superior generalization performance on CIFAR-10
column3: CIFAR-100 & ImageNet and outperforms all previous works under symmetric (uniform) and asymmetric noises.Furthermore
column4: our models remain robust despite the increasing noise ratio and change in network architectures.

column3: 2018. 11  Published as a conference paper at ICLR 2020  A APPENDIX  A.1 MEAN TEACHER MODEL FOR ITERATIVE FILTERING  We apply the Mean Teacher algorithm in each iteration i in the train(Df ilter
column4: Dval) procedure as follows. • Input: examples with potentially clean labels Df ilter from the filtering procedure.

column2: here Df ilter refers to entire labeled dataset. • Initialize a supervised neural network as the student model M s i• Initialize the Mean Teacher model M t  i as a copy of the student model with all weights  detached. • Let the loss function be the sum of normal classification loss of M s  i and the consistency  loss between the outputs of M t  i and M t i  • Select an optimizer • In each training iteration:  – Update the weights of M s – Update the weights of M t – Evaluate performance of M s  i using the selected optimizer i as an exponential moving-average of the student weights i over Dval to verify the early stopping criteria. i and M t  • Return the best M t i  A.2 ASSUMPTIONS DICUSSIONS  Our method performs best when the following assumptions are hold.

column1: Natural robustness assumption of deep networks (Rolnick et al
column2: 2017): The networks attempt to learn the easiest way to explain most of the data.SELF uses this assumption to kickstart the learning process. Correct samples dominate over wrongly labeled samples At 80% noise on CIFAR-10
column3: the cor- rectly labeled cats (20% out of all cat images) still dominates over samples wrongly labeled as cat (8.8% for each class).

column1: Independence results in less overfitting SELF performs best if the noises on the validation set and training set are i.i.d.SELF uses the validation data for early stopping.Hence
column2: a high correlation of label noise between train and valid increases the chance of model overfitting. Sufficient label randomness assumption The subset of all correctly labeled samples capture all samples clusters.

many works from the active learning literature show that less than 100 % of the labeled samples are required to achieve the highest model performance.SELF performs progressive expansion of the correct labels sets.At larger noise ratios
column3: not all clusters are covered by the identified samples.

column1: Therefore on task containing many classes
column2: e.g.
column3: CIFAR-100
column4: the model performance decreases faster than on CIFAR-10. The model performance reduces when these assumptions are strongly violated.Each assumption should have its own ”critical” threshold for violation.

column1: A future in-depth analysis to challenge the assumptions is an interesting future research direction. A.3 TRAINING DETAILS  A.3.1 CIFAR-10 AND CIFAR-100  Dataset Tab.7 shows the details of CIFAR-10 and 100 datasets in our evaluation pipeline.

column1: Data augmentation The data are normalized to zero-mean and standard-variance of one.Further

column1: A.3.2  IMAGENET-ILSVRC-2015  Network Training The network used for evaluation were ResNet He et al (2016) and Resnext Xie et al (2017) for training.All ResNext variants use a cardinality of 32 and base width of 4 (32x4d).ResNext models follow the same structure as their Resnet counterparts
column2: except for the cardinality and base width.

column1: All other configurations are kept as close as possible to Tarvainen & Valpola (2017).The initial learning rate to handle large batches Goyal et al (2017) is set to 0.1; the base learning rate is 0.025 with a single cycle of cosine annealing. Semi-supervised learning Due to the large images
column2: the batch size is set to 40 in total with 20/20 for labeled and unlabeled samples
column3: respectively.

column1: We found the Kullback-divergence leads to no meaningful network training.Hence
column2: we set the consistency loss to mean-squared-error
column3: with a weight of 1000.We use consistency ramp up of 5 epochs to give the mean teacher more time in the beginning.

column1: Weight decay is set to 5e-5; patience is four epochs to stop training in the current filtering iteration. Filtering We filter noisy samples with the topk=5 strategy
column2: instead of taking the maximum- likelihood (ML) prediction as on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100.That means the samples are kept for supervised training if their provided label lies within the top 5 predictions of the model.

column1: The entropy loss can easily be applied to all samples to express the uncertainty about the provided labels.Alternatively

column1: A.4 MORE EXPERIMENTS RESULTS  A.4.1 COMPLETE REMOVAL OF SAMPLES  Tab.8 shows the results of deleting samples from the training set.It leads to significant performances gaps compared to our strategy (SELF)
column2: which considers the removed samples as unlabeled data.

column1: In case of a considerable label noise of 80%
column2: the gap is close to 9%. Continuously using the filtered samples lead to significantly better results.The unsupervised-loss provides meaningful learning signals
column3: which should be used for better model training.
